speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I remain squarely focused on our dual mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We understand the hardship that high inflation is causing, and we remain strongly committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Without price stability, the economy doesn’t work for anyone.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, without price stability, we will not achieve a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since early last year, the FOMC has significantly tightened the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today we took another step by raising our policy interest rate ¼ percentage point, and we are continuing to reduce our securities holdings at a brisk pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve covered a lot of ground, and the full effects of our tightening have yet to be felt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Looking ahead, we will continue to take a data-dependent approach in determining the extent of additional policy firming that may be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ll have more to say about monetary policy after briefly reviewing economic developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Recent indicators suggest that economic activity has been expanding at a moderate pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Growth in consumer spending appears to have slowed from earlier in the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Although activity in the housing sector has picked up somewhat, it remains well below levels of a year ago, largely reflecting higher mortgage rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And higher interest rates and slower output growth also appear to be weighing on business fixed investment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market remains very tight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the past three months, job gains averaged 244,000 jobs per month, a pace below that seen earlier in the year but still a strong pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate remains low at 3.6 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are some continuing signs that supply and July 26, 2023 demand in the labor market are coming into better balance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor force participation rate has Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL moved up since last year, particularly for individuals aged 25 to 54 years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nominal wage growth has shown some signs of easing, and job vacancies have declined so far this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While the jobs-to-workers gap has narrowed, labor demand still substantially exceeds the supply of available workers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation remains well above our longer-run goal of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the 12 months ending in May, total PCE prices rose 3.8 percent; excluding the volatile food and energy categories, core PCE prices rose 4.6 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In June, the 12-month change in the consumer price index, or CPI, came in at 3.0 percent, and the change in the core, core CPI, was 4.8 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation has moderated somewhat since the middle of last year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, the process of getting inflation back down to 2 percent has a long way to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Despite elevated inflation, longer-term inflation expectations appear to remain well anchored, as reflected in a broad range of surveys of households, businesses, and forecasters, as well as measures from financial markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s monetary policy actions are guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I are acutely aware that high inflation imposes significant—significant hardship, as it erodes purchasing power, especially for those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re highly attentive to the risks that high inflation poses to both sides of our mandate, and we are strongly committed to returning inflation to our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At today’s meeting, the Committee raised the target range for the federal funds rate by ¼ percentage point, bringing the target range to 5¼ to 5½ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are also continuing the process of significantly reducing our securities holdings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With today’s action, we’ve raised our July 26, 2023 policy rate by 5¼ percentage points since early last year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have been seeing the effects of our Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL policy tightening on demand in the most interest rate–sensitive sectors of the economy, particularly housing and investment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will take time, however, for the full effects of our ongoing monetary restraint to be realized, especially on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, the economy is facing headwinds from tighter credit conditions for households and businesses, which are likely to weigh on economic activity, hiring, and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In determining the extent of additional policy firming that may be appropriate to return inflation to 2 percent over time, the Committee will take into account the cumulative tightening of monetary policy, the lags with which monetary policy affects economic activity and inflation, and economic and financial developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will continue to make our decisions meeting by meeting, based on the totality of the incoming data and their implications for the outlook for economic activity and inflation, as well as the balance of risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We remain committed to bringing inflation back to our 2 percent goal and to keeping longer-term inflation expectations well anchored.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Reducing inflation is likely to require a period of below-trend growth and some softening of labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Restoring price stability is essential to set the stage for achieving maximum employment and stable prices over the longer run.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude: We understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We at the Fed will do everything we can to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you, and I look forward to your questions.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Steve.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Mr. Chairman, thank you.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: You have, I think a couple of times in your opening remarks, talked about this language “in determining the extent of additional policy firming that may be appropriate.” Should we take that to mean that additional hikes are likely on the way?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: And should we also believe that all future meetings—say, September and November—are live, or are you in an every-other-meeting mode?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we haven’t made a decision to go to every other meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not something we’ve looked at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to be going meeting by meeting, and as we go into each meeting, we’re going to be asking ourselves the same questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we haven’t made any decisions about, about any future meetings, including the pace at which we’d consider hiking.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we’re going to be assessing the need for further tightening that may be appropriate—you read the language—“to return inflation to 2 percent over time.” I would say that the intermeeting data came in broadly in line with expectations: Economic activity remained resilient, job creation remains strong while cooling a bit, and the June CPI report actually came in a bit better than expectations for a change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the June CPI report, of course, was welcomed, but it’s only one report, one month’s data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We hope that inflation will follow a lower path, as was—that will be consistent with the CPI reading, but we don’t know that, and we’re just going to need to see more data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, what are we going to be looking at?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Really, it will be the broader, the whole broader picture, and starting with—we’re looking for moderate growth, right?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re looking for supply and demand through the economy coming into better balance, including, in particular, in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be looking at inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be asking ourselves, does this whole collection of data, do we assess it as suggesting that we need to raise rates further?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if we make that conclusion, then we will go ahead and raise rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how we’re thinking about July 26, 2023 the next meeting and, you know, how we’re thinking about meetings going forward potentially, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL but, you know, we’re now mainly thinking about the next meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will also say, since we’re talking about it, between now and the September meeting, we get two more job reports, two more CPI reports.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we have an ECI report coming later this week—which is [an] employment compensation index—and lots of data on economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All of that information is going to inform our decision as we go into that meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say it is certainly possible that we would raise funds again at the September meeting if the data warrant it, and I would also say it’s possible that we would choose to hold steady at that meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to be making careful assessments, as I said, meeting by meeting, and I’ll close by saying we’ve raised the federal funds rate now by 525 basis points since March 2022.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Monetary policy, we believe, is restrictive and is putting downward pressure on economic activity and inflation.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: If I could just briefly follow up on something you said there: You said the data in the intermeeting period, it probably came in in line with expectations.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Does that mean there’s unlikely to have been a change in the overwhelming outlook of the Committee that two more hikes are necessary?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m just going to go back to what I said.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we—you know, that’s the question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have eight weeks now until the September meeting, and all that data that I recited, we’re going to be looking at all that and making that assessment then.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it really—we did have the one good reading, and, of course, we welcome that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s just one reading, as everybody knows.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and, you know, we’ve seen—we’ve seen this before in the data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many forecasts call for, for rates—for, for inflation to remain low, but we just don’t know that until we see the data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ll be focusing on that.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Jeanna.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Thanks for taking our questions, Chair Powell.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Obviously, you updated the language around growth in the statement today.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: You know, we’ve seen the Barbie movie numbers.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: We’ve seen everyone going to Taylor Swift concerts this summer.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: It seems like the American consumers are in pretty good shape, and it does seem like growth is sort of picking back up a little bit or at least doing well.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: And I wonder, from your perspective, if that continues, if we see growth not just stabilizing but doing, you know, performing well this summer, is that a problem because it’s inflationary, or is it good news because it suggests that a soft landing is more likely?

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Just how are you thinking about that sort of trajectory?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would say it this way: The overall resilience of the economy, the fact that, that we’ve been able to achieve disinflation so far without any meaningful negative impact on the labor market, the strength of the economy—overall, that’s a good thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s good to see that, of course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s also—you see consumer, consumer confidence coming up and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That will support activity going forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you’re, you’re right, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the margin, stronger growth could lead, over time, to higher inflation, and that would require an appropriate response for monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ll be watching that carefully and seeing how it evolves over time.

speaker: MICHELE SMITH
sentence: Neil.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Thanks, Chair Powell.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Neil Irwin from Axios.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: So, as you referenced earlier, in the intermeeting period, soft CPI, jobs reports still strong but moderating, JOLTS look good.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: So if you’re data dependent, why not pause again?

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Why not stay on hold?

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Why not take another meeting off when the data was at least cutting in the direction you want to see?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you go back to what we’re trying to do here, we’re trying to achieve a stance of policy that’s sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the last meeting, we wrote down our individual estimates of that would take—of what that would take, and the median of that was, was an additional two rate hikes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would say, we looked at the interim intermeeting data and, as I mentioned, broadly consistent, not perfectly consistent, but broadly consistent with expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, as a result, we went ahead and, and took another step.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s, you know, a labor market that continues to be strong but, but gradually slowing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mentioned that the inflation report was actually a little better than expected, but, you know, we’re, we’re going to be careful about taking too much signal from, from a single reading.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, growth came in stronger than expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how we look at it, and, and so we did take that step today.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Nick.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Nick Timiraos of the Wall Street Journal.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Chair Powell, markets widely believe the median FOMC participant’s inflation forecast from June for the fourth quarter of this year will be too high, given autos and shelter, and that by September, that may warrant a downward revision in the inflation forecast of 20 to 30 basis points.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Would that type of inflation progress be enough to hold rates steady from here, or do you need to see below-trend growth and decelerating labor income growth to be convinced that you’ve done enough?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s hard to pick the pieces apart and say, you know, how much of this and how much of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’ll be looking at everything.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’ll, of course, we’ll be looking to see whether the signal from June’s CPI is replicated or, or the opposite of replicated or whether it’s somewhere in the middle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be looking at the growth data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be looking at the labor market data very closely, of course, and making an overall July 26, 2023 judgment about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s the totality of the data, I think, but with a particular focus on, on Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL making progress on inflation.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: If I could follow up: Last month you said there were benefits to moderating the pace of increases because it would give you more information to make decisions.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Would another CPI report like the one we just had in June allow you to at least maintain that slower pace and defer until the fall any decision on whether you need that second rate hike?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’m just going to tell you again what we’re going to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In September, we’re going to look at, at two additional job reports, two additional CPI reports, lots of activity data, and that’s what we’re going to look at, and we’re going to make that decision then.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that decision could, could mean another hike in, in September, or it could mean that we decide to maintain at that level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, the question we’re going to be asking ourselves is, is the overall signal one that we need to do more, that we need to tighten further?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if we get that signal, whenever we get it, then—and that’s the collective judgment of the Committee—then we will move ahead.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If we don’t, you know, then, then we’ll have the option of maintaining policy at that level, but it’s, it’s, you know, it’s really dependent so much on the data, and we just don’t have it yet.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Chris.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Hi.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Chris Rugaber at Associated Press.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: So consumer confidence in the economy is rising, likely in large part because of, of the declines in headline inflation.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: You also see wages are also rising faster than prices now after trailing them for a long time.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: How much are Americans truly harmed by inflation at its current level, headline level of 3 percent?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: And with that in mind, when do you put some weight back on the employment side of the dual mandate?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess I’d say it this way: First, it is—it is a good thing that headline inflation has come down so much, because that’s really what the public experiences.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and I would say that having headline inflation move down that much almost creates a—it will strengthen the broad sense that, that the public has that inflation is coming down, which will in turn, we hope, help inflation continue to move down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you are really—sorry, your question was?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Well, I mean, you’ve talked for many press conferences now about the harm created by inflation, how hard it is for people.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: So how much of that are we still seeing with inflation now down at 3 [percent]?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess I would put it this way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we—I’d say it this way: It’s really a question of, how do you balance the two risks, the risk of doing too much or doing too little?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, I would say that, you know, we’re coming to a place where, where there really are risks on both sides.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s hard to say exactly whether, whether they’re in balance or not, but as our—as our stance has become more restrictive and inflation moderates, we do increasingly face that risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, we, we need to see that inflation is durably down that far, you know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As you know, we think, and most economists think, that core inflation is actually a better signal of, of where headline inflation is going, because headline inflation is affected greatly by volatile energy and food prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we would want core inflation to be coming down, because that’s what we think—that’s—core is signaling where headline is going to go in the future.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And core inflation is still pretty elevated, you know?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s reason to think it can come down now, but it’s, it’s still quite elevated, and so we think we need to stay on task, and we think we’re July 26, 2023 going to need to hold, certainly, hold policy at a restrictive level for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we need to Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL be prepared to raise further if that—if we think that’s appropriate.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Well, and then if inflation were to—just a quick follow[up]: If it stays at 3 or drops even a little bit more, I mean, how much of an increase in unemployment do you think is acceptable to get that last bit of inflation?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: People are talking about the potential difficulty of the last, so-called last mile of inflation.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: So—but how much?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Again, how much unemployment do you think is justified to get down that last one— CHAIR POWELL.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: So it is—it is a very positive thing that, actually, the unemployment rate is the same as it was when we lifted off in March of ’22, at 3.6 percent.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: So that’s a real blessing in that we’ve been able to achieve some disinflation, and we don’t seek to it.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: It’s not that we’re aiming to, to raise unemployment, but I would just say, the historical record—we have to be honest about the historical record, which does suggest that when central banks go in and slow the economy to bring down inflation, the result tends to be some softening in labor market conditions.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: And so that is still the, the likely outcome here.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: And, you know, we hope that that’s as little as possible, but we have to be honest that that is—that is the likely outcome.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: The worst outcome for everyone, of course, would be not to deal with inflation now, not get it done.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Whatever the short-term social costs of getting inflation under control, the longer-term social costs of failing to do so are greater, and the historical record is very, very clear on that.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: If you go through a period where inflation expectations are not anchored, inflation is volatile, it interferes with people’s lives and with economic activity, and, you know, that’s the—that’s the thing we, we really need to avoid and will avoid.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Let’s go to Michael McKee.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: At this point, you say the policy is restrictive, but all year long we have seen growth surprise to the upside, unemployment to the downside, and inflation, lately, to the downside.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: So I’m wondering, by definition, should you be restrictive enough right now under these conditions?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Do you think you might need to do more, because I’m curious about what you see as inflation dynamics now?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Is the economy still moving in a direction where it creates more inflation?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: People talk about base effects and higher energy costs, and now we have some large labor settlements.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Or is the economy disinflating, and you’re just, you’re able to go back to the old Fed policy of opportunistic disinflation?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’ll just say again, the broader picture of what we want to see is, we want to see easing of supply constraints and normalization of pandemic-related distortions to demand and supply.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want to see economic growth running at moderate or modest levels to help ease inflationary pressures.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want to see continued restoration of supply and demand balance, particularly in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And all of that should lead to declining inflationary pressures.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now what we see is, we see those pieces of the puzzle coming together.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re seeing evidence of those things now, but I would—I would say that what, what our eyes are telling us is that policy has not been restrictive long, restrictive enough for long enough to have its full desired effects.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we intend, again, to keep policy restrictive until we’re confident that inflation is coming down sustainably to our 2 percent target, and we’re prepared to further tighten if that is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think the process, you know, still probably has a, a long way to go.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Well, do you think under current conditions you are restrictive enough unless something changes?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I think—we think, you know, today’s rate hike was appropriate, and I think we’re going to be looking at the incoming data to inform our decision at the next meeting about, is the incoming data telling us that we need to do more?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if it does tell us that—collectively, if that’s our view—then we will do more.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Colby.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Colby Smith with the Financial Times.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: If September is, in fact, a live meeting, how does that square with the need for a more gradual tightening pace that you spoke of last month in explaining the rationale for holding the funds rate steady at the June meeting?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So a more gradual pace doesn’t go immediately to [moving] every other meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It could be two out of three meetings, right?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It could be—it just means if you’re slowing down, the point really was to slow down the decision cycle as, as we get closer and closer to, we think, our destination.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I wouldn’t want to go automatically to [moving] every other meeting, because I just don’t think that’s—we don’t—I think it’s not an environment where we want to provide a lot of forward guidance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a lot of uncertainty out there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We just want to keep moving at what we think is the right pace, and I do think it makes all the sense in the world to slow down as we now make these finely judged decisions, and so that’s what we did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so I, I think it’s possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mentioned it before.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s possible that we would move at consecutive meetings—we’re not taking that off the table—or we might not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s really going to depend on what the data tell us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s the best we can do.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: So we shouldn’t assume that every other meeting is the lowest tightening frequency, let’s say?

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: It could be, you know, longer intervals in between as well?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we’re—look, I think we’re going to—we’re going to make a decision about the next meeting, and then we’re going to make a decision about the one after that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think it’ll sort itself out.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Howard.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Howard Schneider with Reuters.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: So, among your colleagues, there have been people who’ve said they feel that very little transmission has taken place so far from monetary policy into the economy, and there are those who feel, they say, it’s happened very fast this time, and it’s kind of up to date.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Where are you on that continuum?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s a long-running debate about the lags between changes in financial conditions and the response to those changes from economic activity and inflation, right?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we know that in the modern era, financial conditions move in anticipation of our decisions, and that has clearly been the case in this cycle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in a sense, the clock starts earlier than it—than it used to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that doesn’t necessarily change the process from that point on, and it’s not clear that it has.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also—this is—I’ll tell you what we know and then what we don’t know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know that financial conditions affect economic activity and inflation with a lag that can be long and variable, or lags, plural, that can be long and variable—a lot of uncertainty around the length of the lags.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, that’s just one component of the broader uncertainty that we face.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’ll tell you how I—how I think about this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: First, the first thing to say is, we’re determined to bring inflation down to 2 percent over time, and we will use our tools to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No one should doubt that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would look at it this way, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The real federal funds rate is now in meaningfully positive territory.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you take the nominal federal funds rate, subtract the mainstream estimate of near-term inflation expectations, you get a real federal funds rate that is July 26, 2023 well above most estimates of the longer-term neutral rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would say, monetary policy is Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL restrictive, more so after today’s decision, meaning that it is putting downward pressure on economic activity and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll keep monetary policy restrictive until we think it’s not appropriate to do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how I think about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, if I sum it up, I would say: We’ve come a long way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are resolutely committed to returning inflation to our 2 percent goal over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation has proved, repeatedly, has proved stronger than we and other forecasts—forecasters have expected, and at some point, that may change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have to be ready to follow the data, and given how far we’ve come, we can afford to be a little patient, as well as resolute, as we let this unfold.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: On the—on the credit side, I’m wondering if you saw anything in the—in the latest SLOOS data that made you think you’re getting a quantum of credit contraction beyond what you’d expect.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: The bank lending data really is—the growth rate’s edging down towards below, heading below zero, which is usually, you know, a recession indicator.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess that the SLOOS will come out early next week, and I would just say it’s broadly condition—consistent with what you would expect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’ve got lending conditions tight and getting a little tighter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’ve got weak demand, and, you know, it, it gives a picture of pretty tight credit conditions in the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it’s really hard to tease out whether—how much of that is from this source or that source, but I think what matters is, the overall picture is of tight and tightening lending conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s, that’s what the SLOOS will say.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Rachel.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Rachel Siegel from the Washington Post.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Thanks for taking our questions.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Could you break down the reasons why inflation has fallen and what share of that credit you would give to factors that don’t stem directly from rate hikes or that might be within your control at all, like easing supply chains and a drop in energy prices over the past year?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, interesting question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let me start by saying that the inflation surge that we saw in the pandemic resulted from a collision of elevated demand and, and constrained supply, both of which followed from the unprecedented features of the pandemic and the response from fiscal and monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ve always expected that the disinflationary process would stem from, both from the normalization of those broad pandemic-related supply and demand conditions and from restrictive, restrictive monetary policy, which would help return the balance between supply and demand by restraining demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think that’s broadly what we’re—what we’re seeing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So to go, break it down a little further: Of course, headline inflation has come down sharply from elevated levels as energy and food prices have come down, mostly due to [a] reversal of the effects [on those prices that resulted] from the war in Ukraine.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s, that’s a good thing, and the public experiences that, as I mentioned earlier.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For core inflation, I’d say there also—there has been a role for, for most—for, for both factors, both that I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Clearly, for goods, normalization of supply conditions is playing an important role, as is the reversal, the beginning of the reversal, of spending—back into services and away from goods.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And take autos as an example.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The combination of an increase in sales and inventories, while, while vehicle inflation has decelerated, points to a substantial role for supply, but there’s July 26, 2023 also a role for demand, as, you know, the loans and things like that are more expensive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL they’re both working there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Housing services inflation now starts to move down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Clearly, higher rates have, have slowed the housing market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I would say, monetary policy is working about as we expect, and we think—we think it’ll play an important role going forward, in particular in nonhousing services, where, really, we think that’s, that’s where the labor market will come in as a very, very important factor.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we think both of those—both of those sources of disinflation are playing an important role.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: I see.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: And just to follow up, do you think that of those two sources, that core will rely more heavily on seeing an impact from rate hikes, or is there a more even split there, too?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think monetary policy is going to be important going forward because we, we’re sort of reaping now the benefits of the—of the reversal of some of the very specific pandemic things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re seeing that with goods, in particular, with supply chains and shortages moving, and we’re seeing—so I think going forward, monetary policy will be important, particularly in that, in the sector, in the nonhousing services sector.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Edward.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Thank you, Chair Powell.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: First, let me compliment your tie, the choice of tie.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: It’s a good color.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: So thanks for taking our questions.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: So the Beige Book, it said, “Input cost pressures remained elevated for services firms but eased notably” for manufacturing sectors.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Is that an indication that there’s a, a wage inflation pressure?

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: And how do you target pressure on the wage inflation without pushing the economy into a recession?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think that, as it relates to goods, it’s really an indication that supply chains and, and shortages are easing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so, what was the first part of it?

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: So, wage inflation.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Like, how do you—how do you target wage inflation without pushing an economy into a recession?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t—I don’t think we’re targeting wage inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think what we’re—what we’re looking for is a broad cooling in labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s what we’re seeing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So wages have actually been gradually moving down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re still at levels what would—that would be consistent over a long period of time with 2 percent inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, we’re making progress there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And by so many indicators, labor market demand is cooling.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can—you can look at surveys by workers and businesses who see that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can look at the quits rate normalizing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can look at job openings coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can look at just job creation in the, the establishment survey has, you know—it’s still at a high level, but it was at, really, an extraordinarily high level for most of the last two years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you see cooling, particularly in private sector, in the last, you know, in the last report.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think we see that, and it’s happening at a gradual pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s actually not a bad thing, in a sense, because if, if what we see is a labor market, very strong demand for labor, which is really the engine of the economy—people are getting hired, many people going back to work, getting wages, spending money—and that’s really what’s driving the economy but that it’s gradually slowing, it’s gradually cooling, that’s a good prescription for getting where we want to get.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: But still we see a push to raise minimum wage.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: We’re seeing a lot of unions go on strike or threaten strike, and the common thing is, they come out with agreements like big pay increases, like UPS, and we have the autoworkers coming up.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Are you concerned then about a trend of series of big unions, these contracts, pushing wage inflation then?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Not for us to comment on, on contract negotiations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Not our job, not our role.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we, we monitor these things, and we’ll keep an eye on them, but, really, that’s something that’s, that’s handled at that level and not— MICHELLE SMITH.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Victoria.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Hi.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Victoria Guida with Politico.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: I wanted to ask about the SEP, which suggests that you would cut rates as overall and core PCE get to around or under 3 percent.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: And so I’m wondering, is the level of inflation what’s sort of important there as you think about getting to 2 percent and when you might start cutting rates, or is the speed at which inflation is falling also important?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think you’d take both into account.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think you’d take everything into account when you start cutting rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It would—it would depend on the whole, on a wide range of things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And when, when people are writing down rate cuts next year, you know, it just is a sense that inflation is coming down, and we’re comfortable that it’s coming down, and it’s time to start cutting rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think—but I mean, there’s a lot of uncertainty between what happens, you know, in the next meeting cycle, let alone the next year, let alone the year after that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s, it’s hard to say exactly what happens there, what’s motivating people.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: So if it’s sort of—sort of stubbornly in maybe the high 2s, you wouldn’t necessarily cut rates?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m not going—I’m not saying that at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m not giving you any numerical guidance around that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m saying we would—we’d be comfortable cutting rates when we’re comfortable cutting rates, and that won’t be this year, I don’t think.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It would be—you know, many people wrote down rate cuts for next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the median was several for next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s just going to be a judgment that we have to make then, a full year from now, July 26, 2023 and it’ll be about how confident we are that inflation is, in fact, coming down to our 2 percent Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL goal.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Steve.

speaker: STEVE MATTHEWS
sentence: A good part of Wall Street has become more confident that the Fed is going to be able to engineer a soft landing, and they’ve reduced their forecast for a recession.

speaker: STEVE MATTHEWS
sentence: And I’m wondering if the staff has changed its view on the likelihood of a recession being likely and if you personally have changed your view in terms of becoming more confident that you can achieve a soft landing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s, it has been my view consistently that we do have a shot, and my base case is that we will be able to achieve inflation moving back down to our target without the kind of really significant downturn that results in high levels of job losses that we’ve seen in some past—in some past instances, many past instances of tightening that look like ours.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s been my view.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s, that’s still my view.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think, you know, that that’s sort of consistent with, with what I see today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—but it’s a long way from assured, and, and, you know, we have a lot left to go to see that happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the staff now has a noticeable slowdown in growth starting later this year in the forecast, but given the resilience of the economy recently, they are no longer forecasting a recession.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I just want to note that it’s—that our staff produces its own forecast, which is independent of the forecasts that we as FOMC participants produce.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Having an independent staff forecast as well as the individual participant forecasts is really a strength of our—of our process.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s just a lot of, I think, constructive diversity of opinion that, that helps us make—informs our deliberations—helps us make, I hope, better decisions.

speaker: STEVE MATTHEWS
sentence: And is the reason for optimism that inflation has come down and you still have a strong labor market?

speaker: STEVE MATTHEWS
sentence: I mean, does that add to the optimism?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t use the term “optimism” about this yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would—I would say, though, that there’s a pathway, and, yes, that’s, that’s a good way to think about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve, we’ve seen so far the beginnings of disinflation without any real costs in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s, that’s a really good thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would just also say the historical record suggests that there’s very likely to be some softening in labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And consistent with having a soft landing, you would—you would have some softening in labor market conditions, and that’s still likely as we—as we go forward with this process.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s a good thing to date that we haven’t—we haven’t really seen that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve seen softening through other—not through unemployment, not through higher unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve seen softening through, you know, job openings coming down part of the way back to more normal levels; the quits rate, so people are not quitting as much; we’ve seen participation—people coming in, and so labor supply has, has improved, which has lowered the temperature in the labor market, which was quite overheated, you know, going back a year or so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re seeing that kind of cooling, and that’s, that’s very healthy, and, you know, we hope it continues.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Jeff.

speaker: JEFF COX
sentence: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: JEFF COX
sentence: Jeff Cox from CNBC.com.

speaker: JEFF COX
sentence: You and other Fed officials in the past have suggested that you don’t need to keep hiking until inflation hits 2 percent, that—as long as you see continued progress.

speaker: JEFF COX
sentence: So I’m wondering, how close do you need to get with the inflation numbers coming down?

speaker: JEFF COX
sentence: How many months of data do you need to July 26, 2023 see that will—that will give you sufficient confidence, and how, how far does this fight need to Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL go before you’re willing to kind of declare victory on it?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the idea that we would keep hiking until inflation gets to 2 percent—it would be a prescription [for a policy] of going way past the target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s, that’s clearly not the appropriate way to think about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, and in fact, if you look at our forecast, we, we—the median participant—and, again, these are forecasting out years, so take them with a grain of salt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But people are cutting rates next year because, because, you know, the federal funds rate is at a restrictive level now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if we see inflation coming down credibly, sustainably, then we don’t need to be at a restrictive level anymore.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can, you know, we can move back to a—to a neutral level and then below a neutral level at a certain point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we would, you know, we would—we, of course, would be very careful about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’d really want to be sure that inflation is coming down in a sustainable level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s hard to make—I’m not going to try to make a numerical assessment of when and where that would be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s the way I would think about it, is you’d start—you’d stop raising long before you got to 2 percent inflation, and you’d start cutting before you got to 2 percent inflation, too, because we don’t see ourselves getting to 2 percent inflation until—you know, all the way back to 2—until 2025 or so.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Jennifer.

speaker: JENNIFER SCHONBERGER
sentence: Thank you, Chair Powell.

speaker: JENNIFER SCHONBERGER
sentence: Jennifer Schonberger with Yahoo Finance.

speaker: JENNIFER SCHONBERGER
sentence: It’s been over four months since a handful of regional banks, including Silicon Valley Bank, failed.

speaker: JENNIFER SCHONBERGER
sentence: When you look at credit conditions now, given Banc of California’s acquisition of PacWest, does this acquisition suggest the full impact has not been felt, or are you July 26, 2023 comfortable saying that we’ve seen most of the ripple effects that may have occurred at this Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL point?

speaker: JENNIFER SCHONBERGER
sentence: And how does this play into your outlook for policy?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t want to comment on any particular merger proposal, but I will say, things have settled down for sure out there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Deposit flows have stabilized.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Capital and liquidity remain strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Aggregate bank lending was stable quarter over quarter and is up significantly year over year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Banking-sector profits generally are coming in strong this quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, overall, the banking system remains strong and resilient.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we’re still watching, you know, the situation carefully and monitoring, you know, monitoring conditions in, in the banking sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the, the actual effect on—if you think of a particular set of banks that were, were affected because of their size and business model and things like that, that were more affected by the turmoil in March than others, it’s very hard, as I mentioned; it’s very hard to sort of tease out the effects on this very large economy of ours from them tightening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They may be tightening a little bit more, probably are, than other banks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The SLOOS has been telling us for more than a year that banking conditions are tightening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That process is ongoing, and that will restrain economic growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think—I think we have to take a step back from “I can’t separate those anymore.” I think—I think, basically, we’re just looking at the overall picture, which is one of tightening credit conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s, that’s going to restrain economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is restraining economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how I would look at it.

speaker: JENNIFER SCHONBERGER
sentence: And how is that informing your outlook for setting policy?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think we—that goes—that’s—an expected result of tightening interest rate policy is that—is that bank credit conditions—bank lending conditions would tighten as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so the question is, is it more effective this time because of what happened in May?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I just don’t think we know that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we’re looking at the current data in GDP, and we’re seeing strong spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re seeing a strong economy, and it’s made us confident that we can go ahead and raise interest rates now for the third time since the March events.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I—it seems like the economy is weathering this well, but, of course, we’re watching it carefully and, and expect to continue to do that.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Megan.

speaker: MEGAN CASSELLA
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: MEGAN CASSELLA
sentence: Thanks for taking our questions.

speaker: MEGAN CASSELLA
sentence: Megan Cassella with Barron’s.

speaker: MEGAN CASSELLA
sentence: I wondered on wages if you were at all concerned about any inflationary impact of wages now outpacing inflation, which is likely contributing to the boost in consumer sentiment and the continued strength of the consumer that we’ve been seeing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, [growth in nominal] wages in excess of inflation means [that increases in] real wages are positive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, that’s a great thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we want that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want people to have [gains in] real wages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we want wages to be going up at a level that’s consistent with, with 2 percent inflation over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, [increases in] nominal wages have been coming down gradually, and that’s what we want to see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect to see more of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s just more of what’s consistent over a longer period of time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t really think that, that wages were an important cause of inflation in the first year or so of the outbreak.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would say that wages are probably an important issue going forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Labor market conditions broadly are going to be an important part of, of getting inflation back down, and that’s why we think we need some further softening in labor market conditions.

speaker: MEGAN CASSELLA
sentence: This goes sort of to the balance of risks question, but you mentioned at the start how you’re keeping an eye on consumer activity and whether there might be some sort of a rebound there, and I’m curious what the Fed’s explanation would be to families if further interest rate hikes start to hit the labor market—start to, you know, drive that sentiment back down.

speaker: MEGAN CASSELLA
sentence: What’s the message there of, of why you continue to keep rates elevated or to raise them?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, you know, we have a job assigned to us by Congress to get inflation under control.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think the, the single most important thing we can do to benefit those very families, especially families at the lower end of the income spectrum, is to get inflation sustainably under control and restore price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think that is the most important thing we can do now, and we’re determined to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would just point out that the people who are the most hurt by inflation right away are people who are on a low fixed income, who, you know, when you’re talking about travel or, you know, transportation costs, heating costs, clothing, food, things like that, those—if you’re just making it through each month on your paycheck and prices go up, you’re in trouble right away.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even middle-class people have some resources and can absorb inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People, people on the lower end of the income spectrum have a harder time doing that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we need—we need to get this done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, the record is clear that if we—if we take too long or if, if we don’t succeed, that the pain will only be greater.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s how I would explain what we’re doing.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Simon.

speaker: SIMON RABINOVITCH
sentence: Thank you, Chair Powell.

speaker: SIMON RABINOVITCH
sentence: Simon Rabinovitch with the Economist.

speaker: SIMON RABINOVITCH
sentence: You had said last month that this meeting this week was going to be a live one.

speaker: SIMON RABINOVITCH
sentence: In July 26, 2023 the event, the market had assigned a, you know, a roughly 99 percent probability to the rate Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL move that you announced today.

speaker: SIMON RABINOVITCH
sentence: The decision was, of course, unanimous, and the statement was basically unchanged from last month.

speaker: SIMON RABINOVITCH
sentence: So may I ask, you know, to what extent was the meeting actually a live one?

speaker: SIMON RABINOVITCH
sentence: Was there ever any doubt over the past two days about what the decision was, was actually going to be?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I mean, you could—“Was there doubt?” Look, I would say there’s a range of views on the Committee, and when you see the minutes in three weeks, you’ll see that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a range of views about what we should do at this meeting and what we should do at the next meeting, and it’s a—it’s a process that we go through.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many times when we go into a meeting, the decision is not, you know, fundamentally in doubt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, we have the meeting, and some—some—some meetings are, you know, less uncertain than others, and I’ll just leave it at that.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Let’s go to Evan.

speaker: EVAN RYSER
sentence: Evan Ryser, Market News International.

speaker: EVAN RYSER
sentence: Thank you, Chair Powell.

speaker: EVAN RYSER
sentence: Financial conditions have been loosening at a fairly steady clip in recent weeks—the dollar, the stock market, et cetera.

speaker: EVAN RYSER
sentence: What does that mean for the Fed and being sure that inflation will come down to target?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we monitor, of course, financial conditions, broad financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s the dollar and equities, but—and, you know, we’re, of course, very focused on rates and our own policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we will—we’re going to use our policy tools to—working through financial conditions—to get inflation under control The implication is, you know, we will do what it takes to get inflation down, and in principle, that, that could mean that if financial conditions get looser, we have to do more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But what tends to happen, July 26, 2023 though, is, financial conditions get in and out of alignment with what we’re doing, and, and, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL ultimately, over time, we get where we need to go.

speaker: EVAN RYSER
sentence: If I could also ask about the SEP from June that showed rate cuts—do you expect the Fed to cut nominal rates next year while also continuing QT?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that, that could happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The question is, you know, is that consistent with, with—so if you think about both of them as normalization, imagine it’s a world where things are okay, and it’s time to bring rates down from what are restrictive levels to more normal levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Normalization, in the case of, of the balance sheet, would be to reduce QT or to continue it, depending on where you are in the cycle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So they are two independent things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, really, the active tool of monetary policy is rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you can imagine circumstances in which it would be appropriate to have them working in what might be seen to be just different ways.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that wouldn’t be the case.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Let’s go to Kyle.

speaker: KYLE CAMPBELL
sentence: Thanks, Chair Powell.

speaker: KYLE CAMPBELL
sentence: Kyle Campbell with American Banker.

speaker: KYLE CAMPBELL
sentence: I have a question about the discount window.

speaker: KYLE CAMPBELL
sentence: I’m wondering if, since the bank failures of the spring, if you’ve seen signs that banks have taken more steps to be proactive in assuring that they’re ready to use that facility if they need to and if you have any sort of thoughts on whether policies might be appropriate for making sure that banks sort of test regularly to, to show that they are prepared to use it.

speaker: KYLE CAMPBELL
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s a very important thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And yes to both sides of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, yes, banks are now working to see that they are ready to use the discount window, and we are strongly encouraging them to do that—banks broadly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We did find, as you know, during the events of March and that, you know, that it’s a little clunkier.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It can be a little July 26, 2023 clunkier and not as quick as it needs to be sometimes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So why not be in a situation where, where Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL you’re just much more ready in case you—in case you need to access the discount window?

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Let’s go to Mark Hamrick.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: Mr. Chairman, Mark Hamrick with Bankrate.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: You’ve talked in the past about getting the housing market back into better balance—excuse me—and also that the market might have bottomed.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: Where do you see that situation in balance, or lack thereof, right now, particularly with the restrained, constrained inventory of existing homes that might otherwise be coming onto market at a time when existing homeowners are reluctant to move and, of course, also all of that happening with the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage still around 7 percent on the heels of Fed tightening and with what you’re talking about tightening industry lending standards?

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: Are we getting closer to balance or farther away?

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: What’s your sense?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we’ve got a ways to go to get back to balance, really, for the reasons that you talked about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With existing homes, you know, there are many people who have low-rate mortgages, and whereas they might want to sell in a normal situation, they’re not going to because they have such, so much, value in their mortgage, whch means that supply of existing homes is really, really tight, which is keeping prices up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: On the other hand, there’s, you know, there’s a lot of supply coming on line now, and, and there are people coming in.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A lot of the buyers are, are, you know, first-time buyers coming in, buying at, you know, with these, you know, with these relatively elevated mortgage rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think this will take some time to work through.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Hopefully, more supply comes on line, and, you know, we, we work through it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re still living through the, you know, the aftermath of the—of the pandemic.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: We’ll go to Nancy for the last question.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Nancy Marshall-Genzer with Marketplace.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Russia has pulled out of an agreement allowing shipments of grains, safe passage through the Black Sea, and alternative routes at this point could be closed off.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Just wondering, how could that contribute to higher food prices and inflation generally, and how closely are you watching that?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are watching it, of course, very closely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you’re right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The withdrawal from the Black Sea Grain Initiative does raise concerns about global food security, particularly for poorer countries that import a large share of their food.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Grain prices did go up on this news, but they remain well below their peaks of last spring.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the moves that we’ve seen so far, I would say, are not expected to make a significant contribution to U.S. inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we will be watching that situation carefully.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: So you don’t think it would have a big effect on Fed policy at this point?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Doesn’t.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You wouldn’t say so looking at what we—what we know now.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks very much.
